#3778: To the bunch of guys that sat in the first two rows during Bergeron's first Rock History exam today, the entire rest of class was silently laughing at you. It is literally the most fun and easiest class on campus, yet you losers don't come to any lectures because you think it's gonna be easy and end up looking like retards failing the first exam with flying colors. My friends and I saw you not writing anything down as the songs played, it was honestly embarrassing. Do you have any idea how many people actually WANT to actively be in that class? It has the biggest waiting list of any class in the entire school! How dare you make fools out of yourselves amongst your peers while depriving other students of a great class. You give you UM a bad name. Fuck you guys, seriously.

#3776: Why is everyone on here so freaking angry? Calm the fuck down. I know people make you angry, but that's on you for letting them, just focus on your freaking self and live your life. No one owes you anything.

There's still a cultural stigma against mental illness. Many people who suffer are too ashamed to go seek help because they see it as a weakness or a failing on their part. It's our job to dispel that harmful mindset so that future generations will get the help they need.
Someone mentioned starting a "friends club" sort of thing.  That sounded like a good idea!

There's Canes 4 play, a new initiative on campus to provide stress relieving events on campus that also promote socializing between students.... COPE is an organization on campus where we do as much as we can to promote mental health awareness, reduce the stigma, and provide information about how to get help. There's canes care for canes.  And beyond that  you have your peers, possibly faculty and other mentors on campus you can reach out to.  Message me if you want any more information.  You're right, the number of people seeking counseling services on campus is increasing, and students like me and the counseling center are doing their part to help out as much as we can
Simply having someone to confide in is a very useful tool, be it a friend, family member, counselor, whatever. It can be very difficult to open up, but it really does feel good to.
There are groups at the counseling center that meet weekly.
David Pearl-Schwartz

I don't see how mental illness cannot be taken care of by sitting at Starbucks (either location) and looking at our beautiful campus. Go for a job get your endorphins flowing drive to the beach tan by the pool shop there's so much to do in Miami take advantage of it and I'm sure we'll all be less frazzled

#3775: As anyone who reads this page regularly can tell, we have a mental health crisis on this campus. Yes, the counseling center is a great way to help. However, wait times for an appointment can be around 2 weeks or more. (This is due to the fact that they do not have enough rooms, and can't expand because they're in the middle of a big building.) I'm not saying that you should give up on life because the counseling center won't help. (Apparently, if you're in a crisis, they can usually get you in the same day.) But this epidemic will not be solved by the counseling center alone. I'm guessing there's other mental health resources on campus. If so, where are they and why are they not publicized? How much can these resources actually do for us? What new resources can we create to help all these students struggling? Some studies have found that 1 in 4 college students has a mental illness, including depression. If this issue is so common, why aren't we doing more about it?

#3774: I don't understand why people are so judgmental? I've seen a few secrets on here saying they hate fat people. Why? Some people find it very difficult to stay in shape no matter what they do, and you have no right to say you hate them because of it. Saying you hate someone based on weight, in my opinion, is the same as saying you hate someone based solely on wealth or race. This is the reason other countries think we're dicks. We're so quick to harshly judge people based on appearances. Grow the fuck up and learn that people come in all shapes and sizes. Let them live their life...it's not like you're going to "catch obesity" from them. Who are you to tell them if they can or can't be happy?

Also, I'm not overweight. I'm pretty fit. But that doesn't mean I don't get angry when I see people being complete asshats to other human beings.

#3768: Once I was sitting in the food court last year at night, near Wendys. This guy who works there came up to me and said that I looked a 'perfect specimen'. Then, he asked me if I had ever done acid. I thought it was intriguing that some random Wendys worker came over to me to talk about drugs so I said that I had and he gave me strip of acid and disappeared. I know it wasn't a good idea, but last year I honestly contemplated death a lot and I didn't really care about anything so I took the strip he gave me and started to walk back to stanford. By the time I had gone into my room the entire room had morphed into a tunnel and I stepped inside and at the other end there were two people arguing, a girl and boy, only they didn't look human. They sort of did, but something about them was weird and I could understand what they were saying even though it was in another language. When they noticed i had entered the tunnel and was staring at them they walked towards me and I was frozen. They touched me and I woke up in my bed. That was basically my entire trip. My roomate said that I had been montionless in bed for almost 8 hours. I went back to Wendys to talk to that dude but he wasn't there and I still eat at Wendys a lot just to see if he's there again but he never has been. Still no idea what the hell was that.

Well they needed more conference room space, and ballrooms to host events like the Ray Lewis speech. It makes money for the school, and we didn't pay to build it. Plus it adds value by making that whole lakeside look gorgeous.

As a commuter, that's where I hang out in my down time. I think it's incredibly useful and the study lounge is my favorite place on campus. Just because you may see the negative aspects of something, doesn't mean all of us do.

Of course. There are some great resources on campus and the community regarding grief. The counseling center does grief counseling and also, there's a group called the children's bereavement center near school. They have a support group for young adults on campus every other Tuesday night. We use Hillel to meet. Try calling them. It's free and they serve pizza. It's nice to know that there are others out there that understand loss

#3764: After I understood I will never be with this one girl I have always felt something for, I've just been changing, changing into something I don't like. At the moment I meet a new girl, I feel like the exact same scheme is going to be reproduced and I'll end up asking myself what am I still doing wrong. Right now, I feel like shit, can't focus on anything and ultimately continue asking myself, what is wrong with me that I'm not capable of getting with a girl that knows I would give up on everything for her. Life can be great, but life can be ridiculously painful at some points.

It's commendable that you have a clear goal and that you are working towards it. Everyone has a different function on this earth. Personally, as someone who isn't rich, I believe money is important, but it shouldn't be a top priority. It saddens me when I see doctors/lawyers/politicians/etc who are only interested in making money rather than helping people and changing the world.

I'm living below the poverty line so I get the desire for money but being rich is another thing. Do I want enough money to take care of the people I love? Of course. Is it my primary focus for happiness? No. You won't always have money but you can at least have other people. Every time I've been homeless I've just been glad to have people around to help. I'm not telling you to think differently about money, just understand it isn't a "rich kid" perspective.

I think for the less fortunate, we all have those times (like in the post above) when we think "darn it. Money IS everything" because our situations get really frustrating. But really what we want is to not be at the mercy of other people, to not get the scraps under the table, to be free to enjoy some things that we dream about. Sigh. But thats life.
Money can't buy happiness.  It buys things that make you happy.

#3763: The people who say that money isn't anything, have never been poor. I've only heard rich and upper-middle class people say this. The truth is, money is liberating. It's power. It's a mean to do want you want, to travel. To move forward, to have less limits. I came to college because I wanted to have a chance at being rich, I wanted to put my ambitions towards something that would guarantee I would at least be well off the rest of my life. I don't want my kids to grow up like me. Stop looking down on the kids that are in it for the cash, money does make some people happy. And for many reasons.

I would ask guys their opinion, but I actually don't care. None of the men I've taken home have been hesitant at all and I haven't heard a single complaint... actually, the surprise gets them even more turned on.

idk, maybe TELL THEM? Why do you assume he's going to know that you're not interested unless you tell him so? There's a way to tell him without being mean about it. Fucking communicate. This isn't high school.
Why don't you text him that you aren't interested?
Why don't you be an ADULT and text him your FEELINGS.

Here's the deal, women have been known to play hard to get so as not to seem too eager, you know, to play it cool. So if you're not interested, stop complaining about it, stop being a wimp, and have the courage to let them down. Also, why do they have your number anyway? The only correct answers are 1) you worked on a project together for class 2) you are friends. Basically very few other reasons are acceptable to have a guy's number without expecting him to ask you out.
Guys do this all the time to girls and why can't guys txt us back to let us know? Girls have as much of rights to do the same back.

If you are interested in positivity, you can always check out my page too!!

**IMPORTANT MESSAGE FROM ADMIN**

I've received a few submissions today saying that I'm posting too many negative secrets and not enough positive ones.

First of all, I would just like to say that I go down the list of submissions in order and only remove those that violate my rules (address an individual by name, don't make any sense, attempt to use the page as a free/for sale page, etc.) so if there are a lot of negative posts in a row - I'm not ultimately responsible for that.  

Secondly, I think it's very important to see both the good and the bad.  It's great to see secrets about someone's random act of kindness that reaffirms our faith in humanity or a lighthearted funny story.  But to ignore the negative would not make it go away.  This page is a platform for anonymous confession, and I am not going to dictate that individuals can only use it for their positive confessions. Someone has just as much right to use this page to vent about how much they hate their roommate, how they're struggling with classes, or their immorality.  

If you all would like me to, I can try to balance out the secrets and not post a ton of negative in a row, and mix in future positive posts to temper it.  However - please keep in mind that this could mean a greater wait time for posts and fewer posted at a time, as it would mean I couldn't just go straight down the list of submissions in order.  

As always, I will remove secrets if an individual requests that I do so.  I am always open to constructive feedback, so if you have ideas, feel free to send in a submission, comment on this, or better yet - send me a message and let's have a conversation.
David Guetta
Hey, enjoyed that too! Hmu, add me on Fb. The convo can still go on :)

#3744: A year ago, we became secret fuckbuddies. Why did I, the girl who valued her virginity so much, agree to it? As much as I endeavored to conceal my fervent desires, I fell in love with you. Remember how you always told me that I deserved better than to be treated as a punching bag? Back then, you were so down to earth. Aside from refusing to be seen in public with me, I never questioned your sincerity. I cherished even our insignificant memories: from our first rendezvous to when you gently kissed my forehead. Why would you tell me you loved me, if you didn't? Why wait more than half a year to admit that what we had wasn't real? Time changes everyone, so perhaps I shouldn't be upset. It's been weeks since we last spoke, but I've noticed a change in you long ago. I hate being so cold toward you (remember when you told me not to "lose my kindness"?), but it's my only defense. As you once said, I "deserve better," and thus, I vow to forget you. But as far as everyone knows, I already have.

I'm pledging DLP this semester. I transferred to UM this last fall with absolutely no intention of joining greek life at all, but I feel like I've found a community of men I can relate to. Sure, DLP might not be for you, and that's okay, but don't call us purposeless or illegitimate. No, we don't have a house. No, we don't have a suite in the Panhellenic building. Yes, we have as many brothers and pledges as there are rolls in a baker's dozen. These things do not define whether we are "legitimate".  What does define us is our drive and passion to help out in the community and to make our mark here on campus. Maybe if you got to actually know us, you would feel differently.

I'm not a part of DLP, nor any other part of Greek life, but calling them a joke is something I do not agree with. It's kind of funny how you say UM as a whole is accepting yet you don't accept DLP's existence. Kind of makes you sound like a hypocrite there. And DLP does and contributes plenty to the campus and community around us. Maybe try opening your eyes and check out the things they've done. Also, maybe worry about your own frat then that you're actually a part of, and not DLP.

I see that nobody has liked this post, so whoever this is doesn't hold a popular opinion, which is extremely reassuring.

I'm not sure what you consider to be the definition of a legitimate fraternity or student organization, but we definitely fit the criteria set forth by IFC and COSO.

Also, if UM is so accepting (which you're right, it is for the most part) you should talk to the brothers of other fraternities who are afraid to come out to their brothers and then talk to the sisters of sororities who don't want their boyfriends' fraternities accepting gay men and then talk to the men who have been dropped from the pledge process of certain fraternities after being 'found out'.  Because they all still exist, even on our 'extremely accepting' campus.

And anyway, all of that is besides the point because DLP is not just a fraternity for gay men.  We've had men from all over the spectrum of sexual identity and orientation since the very beginning (including straight, shocker I know). 

To those considering joining, continue to consider it.  And consider all the other fraternities as well.  Gay or straight, you'll find your place in DLP or elsewhere.

And thank you to the others here who commented.  It's nice to see the support.

This is completely ridiculous. I coached DLP for my sorority philanthropy in the fall and initially I was hesitant purely because they were a small organization. They're an amazing group of guys who kick ass and put enthusiasm and hard work into everything that they do. In fact, I think that they showed more effort and commitment to our event than many of the other frats.
sounds like you're still bitter over not getting a bid

First ask yourself. Are you on your phone or laptop or using anything that emits a light before you go to bed? Are you watching or listening to anything stimulating or suspenseful? Doing any of these activities an hour or sometimes even more before you sleep tricks your brain into thinking it isn't time to fall asleep yet. Take 1 hour before you go to bed to go into your 'bed time phase' where you just wind down from the entire day and relax, doing relaxing things like reading a book or listening to calm music. The stasis part I believe is your body is so tired/stressed from the lack of sleep during the week that it just shutsdown and sleeps for 48 hours as you said. And you have no problem doing that because its the weekend and its not like you can't pull all nighters to do other homework. Seems like a vicious cycle and might be driven by subconscious thoughts.
ok this is the way to go. at around 8 or 9 depending on you sleeping time; say like 10 0r 11, go hit the gym work out not just running, this will keep your sleeping regular
I also had sleeping issues. Talk with a doctor, particularly a psychiatrist if you can. I can recommend some good doctors also if it helps. Good luck with everything!

#3686: I don't think it's okay to tell fat people that they should accept themselves the way they are and that they have beauty, it's just society doesn't see it. The truth is, it's not okay to be fat. Being different because you're fat isn't analogous to being different because of your hair or skin color. Being fat isn't something that should be accepted, it should be eradicated. If you're fat, there's something wrong with you. You might eat too much,  or maybe you can't help it or have a disease or hormone in balance that makes you fat. Either way, you're not healthy. Stop eating so much, see a doctor or just stay fat if you want. But don't tell yourself that you're beautiful the way you are and that society is wrong.
